document_data.name: Font of Knowledge
document_data.text: Besides, don't you wish to learn more for those little scribes of the Font of Knowledge? Laughable, that they think themselves worthy to take for themselves the secrets wizardry has wrested from the cosmos. At least this venture has proven fruitful with a number of new pawns and Rhaelnar's Legacy itself within my grasp.
document_data.source: The lich Priamon Rakesk to the captive Oghmanyte thief Raegar Stoneblade<ref>
document_data.Location: The temple stood in the city's [[Waterdeep/Castle Ward|Castle Ward]], amongst a block of buildings just east of [[Swords Street]] and south of [[Tzochail's Race]]. It lay roughly between the [[Halls of Justice]], a temple of [[Tyr]], to the east, and [[Blackstaff Tower]], on the other side of Swords Street. Formerly, the site was used for a block of warehouses.
document_data.Description: It was among the largest temples in the city<ref> and considered beautiful, From the street, stone steps led up to the double-doored entrance.
document_data.Structure: It was a three-story building, converted into a four-story building, and constructed of wood and stone.
document_data.Interior:
From the entrance, one stepped into the Hall of the Binder, a stone-walled entry chamber that rose three stories high. Within stood a mighty statue of Oghma carved from green [[marble]]. He was depicted as a muscular nude man, with very long hair and beard, posed as if about to take flight. Over {{SI|25|ft|long=yes}} above the floor, his outstretched left arm clutched a golden scroll; while apparently just gold sheeting, it was rumored to contain secrets of the gods. This statue had been donated by [[Khelben Arunsun]], the Blackstaff, during the temple's construction and was thought to have once stood in the grounds of Oghma's temple in [[Myth Drannor]]. Climbing it was considered blasphemous.

On either side of the Hall of the Binder, behind the statue, were two sets of double doors, themselves two stories in height. These led into the Great Library of the Binder, which covered four whole floors and included a scriptorium for writing and copying manuscripts.

On the second floor, a keyed two-way ''[[portal]]'' joined a library on the second floor of the [[Zoarstar]], the guildhall of the Scriveners', Scribes', and Clerks' Guild, and to a secret library in a hidden chamber of the [[Maze Level]] of [[Undermountain]].
document_data.Activities:
The temple's Great Library was of course the key service offered by the Font of Knowledge to Waterdeep. It housed the largest and best-quality collection of books and scrolls in the City of Splendors, rivaled only by the New Olamn bardic school; the [[House of Wonder]] temple of [[Mystra]]; the [[Tower of the Order]], guildhall of the [[Watchful Order of Magists and Protectors]]; and the [[House of the Moon]], a temple of [[Sel没ne]], and its own Great Library.<ref> Moreover, it was public library, wherein visitors could view any book. In the late 1400s DR, the temple maintained arrangements with local booksellers to get first pick on tomes on certain topics such as lost history, and would pay well for such texts.

An unofficial sideline was the so-called "Council of Sages", a kind of "market square" for sages, scholars, and experts of all kinds. Although Waterdeep's sages were famously independent, many had begun passing hours at a time in the library each day, so [[adventurer]]s looking to consult one in a hurry took to finding them here. As a result, paid inquiries conducted at the library were taxed at 10% by Sandrew the Wise. The Council of Sages originated in the scholars and librarians recruited by Sandrew to build the Great Library.

Hence, either way, the Font of Knowledge was a good place to go to research all kinds of topics and to find maps, have texts translated, unearth secret lore, as well as to obtain clerical healing. On the side, the priests also produced [[wine]] from their own press.

Finally, the Oghmanyte priests at the Font of Knowledge provided free lessons in reading to all who asked for it, helping Waterdeep to become one of the most literate cities in Faer没n as of the 1490s DR.

Members.Abilities:
Members trained in areas of diplomacy, speaking and deciphering languages, history, religious lore, [[spell]]craft, and concentration.

Those of strong faith and favored by the temple could achieve prodigious feats of research and recall of even the most obscure knowledge, albeit only rarely in their lives. To achieve this, they must conduct research or pray to the Binder for a period of 1 hour in any temple of Oghma.

Many spellcasting members were initiated into the magical secrets of the church.
Members.Known Members:
* Loremaster Most High [[Sandrew]] the Wise, Savant of Oghma, high priest of the temple.
* [[Hroman]], a priest with a leadership position.
* Loremaster [[Gustyl|Gustyl the Curious]], a gnome priest and scholar of mages of the North.
* Loremaster [[Phanar Manthar]], assistant and later successor to Gustyl.
* [[Jhasper Goldtoes]], librarian and expert in trade and commerce.
* [[Hycis Gentilore]], librarian and expert in elven history and culture.
* [[Aria Whucknolls]], librarian, expert in religion and human deities, sister to Cera.
* [[Cera Whucknolls]], librarian, expert in [[demihuman]] languages, sister to Area.
* [[Damlath]], a wizard who helped in the temple's construction.
Members.Notable Sages & Other Visitors:
* [[Sangalor|Sangalor of the Secrets]], a [[mind flayer]] cleric of Oghma living in [[Skullport]] who visited the temple on a regular basis and was potentially considering joining fully.<ref>
* [[Sulphon]], an expert in [[magical beast]]s and [[aberration]]s.
* [[Ilighast Chamnabbar]], an expert in magical traditions; the [[Astral Plane]], [[Ethereal Plane]], and [[Elemental Planes]]; and the histories of dwarves, elves, gnomes, and halflings in [[northwest Faer没n]].
* [[Blackrabbas Khuulthund]], an expert in the flora and fauna of northwest Faer没n.
* [[Alcedor Kolat]], an [[enchanter]] and maker and researcher of [[staves]], [[wand]]s, and other [[magical item]]s.<ref>
* [[Javroun Lithkind]], an expert in geography and human history, genealogy, and politics.
* [[Touras Niveradon]], leader of the [[Cult of Ao]].<ref>{{Cite polyhedron/94/The Cult of Ao: Who Watches Those who Watch over You?|14}}

document_data.History:
{{fq
| text   = We've not got an extra room at the moment. With the building of the new temple and the additional clergy Sandrew has put on, we're packed into these rooms like tuna in a fisherman's hold.
| source = Hroman to Pacys, offering up his own room anyway
| float  = left
| width  = 
| styles = 
}}
While Waterdhavian [[bard]]s, [[sage]]s, and [[wizards]] had a long tradition of venerating the Lord of Knowledge, the [[church of Oghma]] itself did not have a significant presence in the city. That changed when Savant Sandrew arrived in Waterdeep around [[1362 DR]] with the vision to build a temple and library worthy of the Lord of Knowledge in the City of Splendors. He had come from [[Silverymoon]] with a small number of fellow priests and wizards, including [[Damlath]] and his master and they occupied a rowhouse on [[Swords Street]], which served as their temporary temple. The ground-floor shop was used for worship and meetings, while the upper three floors housed the priests.

Over the 1360s DR, Savant Sandrew's hard work and delicate negotiations led to the construction of the Font of Knowledge and the Oghmanytes becoming established as a major faith in Waterdeep. and adding a fourth floor. among them, [[Raegar Stoneblade]], a burglar who would join the church. A school for the city's children was also planned. However, this rise did steal some attention and support previously enjoyed by [[Gond]]'s temple, the [[House of Inspired Hands]].<ref>

Projected to be finished before [[Midsummer]], construction was completed in Midsummer in the {{YearlinkName|1368}}. The clergy and books moved in and the Font of Knowledge opened that year with the largest and best collection of books in all of Waterdeep. It enjoyed a sharp increase in attendance and donations, as well as popularity across the North. However, certain folk back in Silvermoon disdained it for what they saw as attempts to replicate the achievements of their own city, while several Waterdhavian noble scions emigrated to Silverymoon.<ref>

Nevertheless, work on the temple continued through [[Ches]] of the following year, and the Swords Street rowhouse remained in use for housing.<ref group="note">While ''Faiths & Avatars'' and ''City of Splendors: Waterdeep'' have the temple completed on time in Midsummer of 1368 DR, the novel ''Rising Tide'', published between the two, describes it as still under construction in 1369 DR. It seems likely that the temple is open and operational, but work continues on some parts, such as priest quarters. On [[Ches 30]] of the {{YearlinkName|1368}}, the priest Hroman allowed the old bard Pacys to stay at the rowhouse after he entertained the priests there.

On [[Uktar 29]] of the {{YearlinkName|1374}}, the [[lich]] [[Priamon Rakesk|Priamon "Frostrune" Rakesk]] [[Dominate person|dominated]] the Oghmanyte ex-thief [[Raegar Stoneblade]] and compelled him to steal the golden scroll from the statue of Oghma, in the belief it was an [[artifact]] of [[Rhaelnar's Legacy]]. He burst into the Hall of the Binder and scaled the statue, while three pursuing [[sharn]] emerged from portals and slew those in the Hall who tried to stop them. Fortunately, Khelben the Blackstaff and [[Tsarra Chaadren]], and her [[tressym]] [[Nameless]] intervened and rescued Raegar, when they came to meet with Sandrew. However, the golden scroll scroll was magically stolen.

A century later, in the {{YearlinkName|1479}}, the Font dispatched Brother [[Cieran]] to purchase a book, ''[[Lexicon on the History of Thay]]'', from a local bookseller, [[Gannon]]. Unfortunately, [[devil]] agents of [[Asmodeus]] sought to suppress this work and got their hands on it first.{{Cite organized play/LFR/Ages Best Forgotten|4,6}} Later that year, adventurers may have researched [[Morgan Estelmer]] at the library.<ref>{{Cite organized play/LFR/Gilding a Noble|10,11}}

Around [[1492 DR]], [[Halaster Blackcloak]] was [[scrying]] on the Font of Knowledge, amongst other Waterdhavian landmarks, via a false portrait kept in the [[Halaster's Tower]] [[demiplane]] accessed from [[Undermountain]].
document_data.Relations:
The Font of Knowledge maintained a strong alliance with the [[New Olamn]] bardic college and close links with the [[Scriveners', Scribes', and Clerks' Guild]]. Further afield, there was a free flow of information between the Font of Knowledge, New Olamn, and the [[Vault of Stars]] and various libraries of Silverymoon.<ref>

The temple also received significant funding from two of Waterdeep's noble houses, [[House Estelmer]] and [[House Majarra]].

Under High Harper [[Eather Heilean]] in the early 1370s DR, the [[Harpers]] of Waterdeep slowly began to work more closely with the clergy of Oghma, as well as those of [[Milil]], [[Sune]], and [[Tymora]].<ref>
